awd_titl_txt: The Role of Social Organization in the Organization of Complex Society
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Izumi Shimada, of Southern Illinois University, together with colleagues will conduct research on the nature and means of social and political integration, highlighting the importance of kinship and shared religion. Earlier studies on this topic have emphasized the role of political economy and control of resources and production, coercive actions or sponsorship of public events. Kinship connections and cooperative behaviors were downplayed. The resultant models accordingly stressed the strongly centralized and hierarchical character of sociopolitical organization. Archaeology, particularly in collaboration with complementary fields, is well placed to illuminate factors and processes that promote stable and effective sociopolitical integration, a topic that has been a pervasive concern for studies of complex societies past and present. In contrast to previous studies, this research highlights instead the importance of kinship or the degree and nature of genetic affinity to the real or fictional ancestors and shared religious beliefs and rituals, thereby significantly broadening the perspective on factors and hierarchical and non-hierarchical means of achieving such integration. Not only does this research promote international and interdisciplinary dialogue and collaboration, but also American and Peruvian student and postdoctorate training. In addition, it will enrich the public display at the Sican National Museum that represents an effective sharing of research results with both Peruvian and the non-Peruvian public. 
 
 Monumental architecture built by many complex societies past and present serves as an impressive, durable symbolic marker of power, prestige and identity of associated groups. What then do multiple coexistent monuments built close in time and space at a single location signify about group(s) that built them? This question guides the field research in the Lambayeque region on the north coast of Peru by Dr. Shimada and his team. Taking advantage of the fact that monuments at the 1000-year old Sican capital have closely associated cemeteries, the investigators will excavate burials that have been located in previous seasons of fieldwork and carry out multiple detailed analyses of human skeletons, ceramic, metal and other funerary objects as well as their associated styles and images. Results from skeletal analysis, including ancient DNA, signs of developmental health, and statistical analysis of numerous measurements taken on teeth will illuminate genealogical relationships and life style of individuals being compared. Ratios of carbon, nitrogen and strontium isotopes defined from skeletal samples will in turn inform on dietary composition and geographic origins of the same individuals. In addition, determination of choices of techniques, styles, images, and/or raw materials used in manufacturing of funerary objects further aid in distinguishing artisans and larger groups to which they pertain.  Employing the above multi-disciplinary methodology, the research team will test three competing hypotheses regarding the importance of kinship and shared religious beliefs. Test results will be integrated into an expanding, regional funerary, DNA and other biological database that will serve as a referential base for years to come.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Monumental adobe-brick temple mounds, locally known as huacas, that are of different sizes, shapes, cultures, periods and/or inferred functions are among the most notable archaeological features of the north coast of Peru, the area that has long been regarded as a center of primary cultural developments. The key question that guided our research was: What do the multiplicity and coexistence of such monumental temples at a single site represent about group(s) that built them? Our study focused on the Middle Sicán (900 and 1100 CE) capital of Sicán in the mid-La Leche Valley on the north coast that featured six distinctly shaped huacas that were built in the same basic manner close in time and apparently in a planned manner around the central plaza. Middle Sicán culture held sway over much of the north coast and disseminated the religion centered around the Sicán Deity between 900 and 1100 CE. Our prior excavations at the cemetery associated with one of the huacas indicated that it    was reserved for social elites who practiced endogamy and worshipped the Sicán Deity. We aimed to test three competing hypotheses that posited (1) these huacas represented six elite lineages that were not genealogically related to each other but shared the same religious ideology; (2) the huacas symbolized six genealogically related groups that also shared the same religion; or that (3) they represent six successive rulers who worshipped the same religion.

            To test these hypotheses, an international team of the Sicán Archaeological Project under the co-direction of Izumi Shimada and Rafael Valdez conducted excavations at the two best preserved huacas, Huaca Loro (HL) and Huaca Lercanlech (HLe) in 2018 and 2019. The 2018 excavations focused on the metal workshop at the NE corner of HL and the SE corner of HLe where we suspected the presence of a similar metal workshop. We did not find a metal workshop at HLe, although abundant metallurgical remains we recovered suggested its presence nearby.  The 2019 excavations focused on the eastern and southeastern basal areas of the HLe mound resulting in the discovery of 16 complete and partial sacrificial human burials.

            Samples of excavated ceramic and metallurgical remains and human skeletons were subjected to a series of detailed technical analyses; for example, ancient DNA and isotopes of carbon, oxygen, and strontium (for dietary and provenance information) of human remains. Chemical characterization of ceramic and metallurgical remains was determined to differentiate products of different workshops. Isotope analyses indicated human remains from the two huacas were quite similar to each other and that they were consistent with a largely “local” population. Ancient DNA analysis revealed a relatively high frequency of Haplogroup C which was relatively rare in northern Peru but could have resulted from endogamy. Nuclear genomic analysis is currently being done for one individual, the first case for the region. Ceramic analysis revealed that both the HL and HLe temple complexes obtained their fine ceramics from the same workshops that apparently shared the clay paste recipes, suggesting that HL and HLe had a peaceful or even a fraternal relationship. Metallurgical analysis also did not reveal any notable differences in production practice or products between two huacas, although the production of precious metal items was largely restricted to the HL workshop. 

            While we were not able to test the three competing hypotheses in a manner we had hoped – largely due to the failure to find the inferred metal workshop and burials with associated grave goods at HLe - our project effectively demonstrated the feasibility and productivity of an international, multi-institutional, multi-pronged, and cross-disciplinary approach. This approach proved to be highly effective, generating various lines of evidence that shed new light on the nature of the Middle Sicán sociopolitical organization. Our finding calls for a serious reassessment of the centralized hierarchical models of political organization of pre-Hispanic polities in the Andes and the attendant presumption of top-down, heavy-handed control of key productive activities. Our study generated evidence that suggests that the Middle Sican polity with its own impressive material and organizational achievements, some unprecedented in scale and complexity, had a sociopolitical organization that was not centralized, unified, or strictly hierarchical; rather, it appears to have been comprised of multiple groups that were bound together through their shared religion and cooperated in sharing resources and technological knowledge and expertise. In other words, the Middle Sican polity seems to have emphasized horizontal connections among contemporary peers for its governance. This heterarchical, cooperative model of sociopolitical organization dovetailed well with the multiplicity of similarly sized, contemporaneous temple mounds in the Sicán heartland, that were associated with the same religion centered around the Sicán Deity. In essence, our project demonstrated unifying centripetal power of Middle Sican religion.
